title: Soapmaking Acronyms and Glossary - Complete Reference
author: Soapmaking Forum Community / @IanT / @IrishLass
overview: Comprehensive glossary of soapmaking acronyms, bath and body terms, supplier codes, and technical definitions

supplier_acronyms.BCS: Bittercreek South Candle and Soap Supply
supplier_acronyms.NG: Nature's Garden Candle and Soap Supplies

CP.description: No external heat applied to raw soap batter to achieve saponification
CP.advantages: Free-flowing batter for complex swirling, smooth finished bars

HP.description: Raw traced soap batter cooked until full saponification (no unreacted lye)
HP.texture: Thick and mashed potato-like at pour time
fluidity_tips: Add powdered goat milk or coconut milk during cook

CPHP.description: Raw traced batter cooked in crock pot on low until full saponification

CPOP.description: Normal CP brought to trace and molded, then placed in warm oven to encourage gel
CPOP.purpose: Speeds up saponification for those who prefer gelled soap

key_definitions.saponification: Chemical reaction whereby oil/fat turns into soap by mixing with alkali (NaOH or KOH)

superfat.definition: Adding extra oil/fat to soap batter beyond 1:1 ratio with lye
superfat.purpose: Safety cushion to prevent lye-heaviness, adds conditioning

lye_discount.definition: Using less lye than needed to saponify all oils 1:1
lye_discount.difference_from_superfat: Calculated up-front rather than added at trace

cure.definition: Setting freshly cut soap aside for days/weeks/months
cure.purpose: Soap dries out, hardens, improves pH, gentleness, longevity, lathering
cure.minimum: 4 weeks for both CP and HP
cure.note: May need longer depending on recipe

gel_phase.definition: Exothermic reaction speeds up, batter enters temporary liquid crystalline state
gel_phase.appearance: Darkens, turns translucent, starts from middle spreads outward
advantages: Full saponification achieved quicker, less likely to zap
Soap can be unmolded and cut quicker
Colors more brilliant (reds stay red instead of pink)
Less chance of heavy ash on surface
Gelled soap slightly less water soluble (lasts longer)

DOS.appearance: Orange, yellow or brown spots on finished bars
DOS.cause: Oxidation of unsaturated fatty acids in presence of trace metals (Dr. Kevin Dunn)
prevention: Limit linoleic acid to no more than 15%
Add ROE to unsaturated oils stored at room temp
Avoid curing on metal racks (use parchment paper barrier)
Add tetrasodium EDTA (diluted) to bind metals

trace.definition: When spoon moved through batter leaves visible line/trail
trace.indicates: Emulsification complete, ready to add additives and pour

tongue_test_zap_test.purpose: Discern if unreacted lye remains in soap
tongue_test_zap_test.CP_timing: When unmolded soap is 3 days to 1 week old
tongue_test_zap_test.method: Wet finger, rub soap surface for lather, touch tip of tongue
tongue_test_zap_test.zap: Immediate stinging = not safe yet, test again in few days
tongue_test_zap_test.no_zap: Safe to use (still needs to cure)

other_definitions.absolute: Most concentrated form of fragrance from semi-solid essential oil extract
other_definitions.carrier_oil: Oil used to carry fragrance, usually oils without strong scent (like sweet almond)
other_definitions.decoction: Herbal preparation made by heating herb in water and reducing by evaporation
other_definitions.essential_oil: Volatile oil from plants with characteristic odor, used in perfumes, flavors, pharmaceuticals
other_definitions.exfoliant: Product/ingredient to remove dead skin cells and dirt
other_definitions.fractionated_oil: Oil processed to separate components for specific properties
other_definitions.hydrosol: Fragrant water from steam distillation of essential oils (flower water)
other_definitions.infused_oil: Oil produced from herbs steeped for weeks/months to absorb properties
other_definitions.rebatch: Melting and redoing a recipe with ingredient changes
other_definitions.sniffie: Fragrance oil sample on cotton ball or Q-tip
other_definitions.tincture: Herbal preparation from steeping in alcohol

quiz_questions.q: What does DOS stand for and what causes it?
quiz_questions.a: Dreaded Orange Spots - caused by oxidation of unsaturated fatty acids in presence of trace metals
quiz_questions.explanation: Prevent with ROE, low linoleic acid, EDTA, avoiding metal racks

quiz_questions.q: What is the difference between superfat and lye discount?
quiz_questions.a: Same concept - superfat adds extra oil at trace/after cook; lye discount reduces lye in up-front calculations
quiz_questions.explanation: Both provide safety cushion against lye-heavy soap

quiz_questions.a: Cold Process Oven Process - normal CP molded then placed in warm oven to encourage gel
quiz_questions.explanation: Used by those who prefer gelled soap for faster saponification

quiz_questions.a: Touch lathered soap to tongue tip - stinging/zap means unreacted lye remains, not safe yet
quiz_questions.explanation: Test CP soap at 3 days to 1 week, HP after gel stage
